repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Education Sector Development
            Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector
            Development Support Credit Project for Bangladesh were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, the Borrower performance was satisfactory,
            sustainability was likely, and institutional development
            impact was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it
            is recommended that the grant-based financing scheme be
            piloted in new schools to test its attractiveness and
            merits, its potential impact on school performance as well
            as to appreciate the degree of buy-in by teachers and School
            Management Committees (SMCs). Ministry of Education (MOE) is
            shifting to grants-based financing system, where resources
            going to institutions will be linked more closely to
            students on a per capita basis, rather than to teachers as
            it is currently the case. A draft grants-based financing
            system has been finalized but not yet adopted and a decision
            was taken to suspend Monthly Pay Order (MPO) for new non
            government schools. As a result, newly registered schools
            are likely to experience financial constraints which may
            have adverse effect on their performance. There is a need to
            improve the capacity of Bangladesh Bureau of Education
            Information and Statistics (BANBEIS) to provide regular
            updates on schools and better monitor education outcomes
            since the last school census was conducted in 1999 and an
            update was undertaken in 2005. BANBEIS is expecting to start
            by June 2008 the next census as it is already approved and
            the process of releasing the funds has begun. There may also
            be a need to develop a platform for integrating multiple
            databases that fall under MOE as was already evidenced by
            the uniformization of school codes between Education Boards
            and BANBEIS. This integration process, across various units
            of MOE, would, for instance, help to institutionalize
            student learning assessment as Secondary Education Quality
            and Access Enhancement Project (SEQAEP) project intends to
            do by benchmarking learning levels in Bangladesh to
            international standards such as Trends in International
            Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) or Program for
            International Student Assessment (PISA).

repnme.cdata!:
Better governance improves quality of
            education in Bangladesh

abstracts.cdata!:
While Bangladesh has made impressive
            gains in access to education, governance constraints have
            contributed to the poor quality of education at all levels.
            The World Bank has supported the implementation of
            substantive policy reforms through a series of development
            support credits - education sector development support
            credit (ESDSC) I and II. There has been an appreciable
            improvement in quality of the secondary education system,
            with 80,000 more children passing grade 12 (as the pass
            rates increased from 40 percent in 2001 to 48 percent in
            2004), and improved governance and transparency in the
            system, including a fall in teacher absenteeism. The Bank is
            assisting the government in undertaking the third phase of
            the reform agenda aimed at addressing systemic governance
            issues in order to raise the quality and cost-effectiveness
            of service delivery, and improve equity of access to
            secondary education.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - 2nd Programmatic Education
            Sector Development Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Programmatic Education Sector
            Development Support Credit Project will assist the Ministry
            of Education (MoE) in undertaking the second phase of a
            medium-term reform agenda, aimed at addressing systemic
            governance issues in order to raise the quality, and
            cost-effectiveness of service delivery, and improve equity
            of access to secondary education. The reform agenda focuses
            on: 1) Accountability, - with reforms enforcing the
            establishment of institutions, and institutional mechanisms
            to link school subventions to objective measures of school
            performance. 2) Equity - through demand-side interventions
            to encourage rural girls' attendance at secondary
            schooling. 3) Administration/Capacity Building - to
            strengthen MoE's planning and policy making capacity,
            and, towards greater implementation responsibility at lower
            levels. 4) Monitoring, Evaluation and Dissemination -
            significantly emphasizing program evaluation and monitoring
            to guide policy and planning. Public expenditure tracking
            surveys and impact evaluation of programs are being
            undertaken. 5) Teachers' Quality -through the
            establishment of an autonomous Non-Government Teacher
            Registration and Certification Authority, responsible for
            the development and selection for the pre-qualification and
            certification of teachers. An apex institution will be
            responsible for the management of teacher training, and to
            regulate training institutions. 6) Textbook Production and
            Curriculum Development - through the National Curriculum and
            Textbook Board (NCTB), a transparent process of textbook
            evaluation and approval will be achieved, with the
            curriculum wing of NCTB being strengthened to enable its
            performance effectively. While risks exist, namely in the
            macroeconomic aspect, political climate, in corruption, and
            capacity constraints, actions are being taken in economic
            management and fiscal adjustment; there is strong
            stakeholder support, and reforms are being openly
            publicized; and, the project strategy is designed to deliver
            benefits that far outweigh the risks.
